beginner.question: You receive an email from 'accounts@paypa1-security.com' asking you to verify your account immediately. What should you do?
options: Click the link and enter your password
Delete the email - it's a phishing attempt
Forward it to your friends to warn them
Reply asking for more information
beginner.explanation: This is a classic phishing email! Notice the suspicious domain 'paypa1' (with number 1 instead of 'l'). Legitimate companies never ask for passwords via email. Always verify by going directly to the official website.

beginner.question: Which of these is the STRONGEST password?
options: password123
P@ssw0rd!2024
Tr0p!c@l$unset#Mango42
MyBirthday1990
beginner.explanation: The strongest password is long (16+ characters), uses a mix of upper/lowercase, numbers, symbols, AND isn't based on dictionary words or personal info. 'Tr0p!c@l$unset#Mango42' combines all these elements!

beginner.question: You want to buy something online. Which URL indicates a SECURE website?
options: http://amazonsale.com/deals
https://www.amazon.com
www.amazon-deals.tk
http://amazon.cheapdeals.net
beginner.explanation: Look for 'https://' (S = Secure) and the official domain! The padlock icon in your browser also indicates encryption. Avoid suspicious domains like .tk or misspelled variations.

beginner.question: A stranger calls claiming to be from IT support, asking for your login credentials to 'fix your computer'. What do you do?
options: Give them the information - they're from IT!
Ask for their employee ID and callback number, then verify with your company
Hang up immediately without verifying
Give them partial information to test if they're real
beginner.explanation: This is social engineering! Real IT support never asks for passwords. Always verify by calling back through official channels. Attackers rely on urgency and authority to trick you.

beginner.question: You receive a popup saying 'Your computer is infected! Click here to clean it now!' What should you do?
options: Click the button to clean your computer
Close the popup and run your actual antivirus software
Call the phone number shown on the popup
Download the recommended software
beginner.explanation: This is scareware - fake security warnings designed to trick you into downloading malware! Close the popup, never click anything, and run your legitimate antivirus software.

intermediate.question: You receive an email with subject 'Urgent: Your package is delayed'. The email has correct company branding and a tracking link. How do you verify it's legitimate?
options: Click the tracking link in the email
Check the sender's email address carefully and verify on the company's official website directly
Trust it because it looks professional
Forward to friends asking their opinion
intermediate.explanation: Advanced phishing emails can look very professional! Always verify the sender's EXACT email address. Go directly to the company's official website instead of clicking email links. Check for subtle domain variations like 'fedex-tracking.com' vs 'fedex.com'.

intermediate.question: What is the MOST secure form of Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)?
options: SMS text message codes
Email verification codes
Hardware security key (like YubiKey)
Security questions
intermediate.explanation: Hardware security keys are the most secure 2FA method! SMS can be intercepted (SIM swapping), emails can be hacked, and security questions can be guessed. Physical keys require direct possession and resist phishing.

intermediate.question: You're at a coffee shop and need to check your bank account. The shop offers free WiFi. What's the SAFEST approach?
options: Use the public WiFi directly - it's convenient
Use your mobile data or connect through a VPN
Only check non-sensitive sites on public WiFi
Ask the staff if the WiFi is secure
intermediate.explanation: Public WiFi is easily intercepted! Attackers can set up fake hotspots or sniff traffic. For sensitive activities (banking, email), use mobile data or a trusted VPN that encrypts your connection.

intermediate.question: Your favorite gaming website was hacked and user passwords were leaked. You use the same password on multiple sites. What should you do FIRST?
options: Change the password only on the hacked website
Wait to see if your other accounts are compromised
Immediately change passwords on ALL sites where you used that password
Delete all your accounts
intermediate.explanation: Password reuse is dangerous! When one site is breached, hackers try those credentials everywhere (credential stuffing). Change that password EVERYWHERE immediately, then use unique passwords for each site. Consider a password manager!

intermediate.question: A LinkedIn message from a 'recruiter' at a major company offers an amazing job. They want to interview you via a suspicious video chat platform you've never heard of. Red flag?
options: It's fine - recruiters use different platforms
Verify the recruiter on LinkedIn and suggest a known platform like Zoom or Teams
Download the platform - you don't want to miss this opportunity!
Share your resume with personal details immediately
intermediate.explanation: This could be a sophisticated social engineering attack! Fake recruiters trick people into downloading malware or stealing personal info. Always verify through official company websites and use established platforms.

advanced.question: What is end-to-end encryption, and why is it important for messaging apps?
options: Encryption that only protects data during transmission
Encryption where only sender and recipient can read messages - not even the service provider
Encryption that requires a physical key
Encryption only for passwords
advanced.explanation: End-to-end encryption (E2EE) means messages are encrypted on your device and only decrypted on the recipient's device. Even the service provider can't read them! Apps like Signal use E2EE. This protects against data breaches and surveillance.

advanced.question: Your computer files are encrypted and a message demands $500 in Bitcoin to unlock them. What's the BEST response?
options: Pay immediately to get your files back
Disconnect from network, don't pay, report to authorities, restore from backups
Try to decrypt the files yourself
Ignore it - the files will unlock eventually
advanced.explanation: This is ransomware! Never pay - it funds criminals and doesn't guarantee file recovery. Immediately disconnect to prevent spread, report to authorities (FBI IC3), and restore from your offline backups. This is why regular backups are crucial!

advanced.question: A 'zero-day vulnerability' is discovered in popular software. What does this mean?
options: The software will stop working in zero days
A security flaw unknown to the vendor with no patch available yet
Free software that costs zero dollars
Software that was released today
advanced.explanation: A zero-day is a vulnerability that's being exploited BEFORE the vendor knows about it or can create a patch. These are extremely dangerous because there's 'zero days' of protection. Stay updated, use security software, and follow security news!

advanced.question: A mobile app requests permissions for: Camera, Microphone, Contacts, Location, and Storage. It's a simple flashlight app. Should you grant these permissions?
options: Yes - all apps need these permissions
No - flashlight apps only need camera permission for LED access, others are suspicious
Yes - but only Location for better service
It doesn't matter - apps can't do anything harmful
advanced.explanation: This is over-permissioning - a red flag! A flashlight only needs camera/LED access. Requesting Contacts, Microphone, Location suggests data harvesting. Always check app permissions and deny unnecessary ones. Privacy matters!

advanced.question: You accidentally clicked a suspicious email link on your work computer. What should you do IMMEDIATELY?
options: Keep working and hope nothing happens
Disconnect from network, report to IT security immediately, change passwords from a clean device
Run a virus scan and continue working
Delete the email and forget about it
advanced.explanation: Quick incident response is critical! Disconnect to prevent lateral movement, report to IT/security team immediately (no shame - it happens!), and change credentials from a clean device. Fast action can prevent a major breach. Being honest saves the company!
